instructions: Roast the eggplant on an open flame until charred. Peel and mash the eggplant.
In a pan, heat oil and add cumin seeds, chopped onions, green chilies, and ginger-garlic paste.
Sauté until golden, then add tomatoes, turmeric, red chili powder, and salt. Cook until oil separates.
Mix in the mashed eggplant and cook for a few minutes.
Garnish with coriander leaves and serve with roti.
Heat oil in a handi (traditional pot). Add sliced onions and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a minute.
Add chicken pieces and cook until browned.
Stir in yogurt, chopped tomatoes, and spices. Cover and cook on low heat until chicken is tender.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve with naan.
Cook lentils until soft and set aside.
In a pan, heat ghee and add cumin seeds. Once they splutter, add chopped onions.
Sauté until golden, then add ginger-garlic paste and chopped tomatoes.
Cook until the mixture is soft, then add cooked dal, turmeric, and salt.
Simmer for 10 minutes, garnish with fresh coriander, and serve with rice.
Boil and mash the mixed vegetables.
Heat butter in a pan and add cumin seeds.
Add chopped onions and sauté until golden.
Stir in ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add tomatoes, pav bhaji masala, and salt. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Add the mashed vegetables and mix well. Cook for a few minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve hot with buttered pav.
Mix mashed potatoes with chopped green chilies, coriander leaves, and salt.
Form the mixture into small balls.
Dip the balls in a batter made from chickpea flour and fry until golden.
Slice the pav and spread green chutney and garlic chutney inside.
Place the vada inside and serve with fried green chilies.
Marinate chicken pieces in yogurt, lemon juice, and tandoori masala. Let it sit for a few hours.
Preheat the oven and cook marinated chicken until cooked through.
Serve with mint chutney and garnish with fresh coriander.
Cook soaked kidney beans until soft.
In a pan, heat oil and add cumin seeds, chopped onions, and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and chopped tomatoes. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Stir in the cooked kidney beans, spices, and salt. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Serve with cooked rice and garnish with fresh coriander.
Cook soaked chickpeas until soft.
In a pan, heat oil and add cumin seeds, chopped onions, and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and chopped tomatoes. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Stir in the cooked chickpeas, chole masala, and salt. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Fry bhature dough until golden and serve with chole.
In a pan, heat oil and add chopped onions. Sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Add chopped tomatoes, misal masala, and salt. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Stir in mixed sprouts and add water. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Serve hot garnished with coriander leaves and pav.
Rinse flattened rice in water and drain.
In a pan, heat oil and add mustard seeds. Once they splutter, add chopped onions and green chilies.
Sauté until onions are translucent, then add peas and turmeric powder.
Add the rinsed poha and salt. Mix well and cook for a few minutes.
Garnish with coriander and lemon juice before serving.
Soak basmati rice in water for 30 minutes, then drain.
In a pot, heat oil and fry sliced onions until golden brown. Remove half for garnishing.
In the same pot, add ginger-garlic paste and chicken pieces. Cook until chicken is browned.
Stir in chopped tomatoes, yogurt, biryani masala, and salt. Cook until chicken is tender.
Layer the partially cooked rice over the chicken. Add mint and coriander leaves on top.
Cover and cook on low heat until rice is fully cooked.
Garnish with fried onions and serve with raita.
Slit the brinjals and stuff with a mixture of peanut powder, sesame seeds, turmeric, chili powder, coriander powder, and salt.
In a pan, heat oil and sauté chopped onions until golden.
Add the stuffed brinjals and chopped tomatoes. Cook covered until brinjals are soft.
Serve hot with rice or roti.
Heat oil in a pan and sauté sliced onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and meat pieces. Brown the meat on all sides.
Stir in yogurt, Rogan josh spice mix, turmeric, and salt. Cook until meat is tender.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve with rice or naan.
In a pan, heat oil and add cumin seeds. Once they splutter, add chopped onions.
Sauté until golden, then add ginger-garlic paste and chopped tomatoes.
Stir in boiled potatoes, dum aloo spice mix, and salt. Mix well.
Cover and cook on low heat for 10-15 minutes. Garnish with fresh coriander and serve.
Boil mustard greens and spinach until soft. Drain and blend to a coarse paste.
In a pan, heat ghee and add chopped onions and ginger-garlic paste. Sauté until golden.
Add chopped green chilies and cornmeal. Mix well.
Stir in the blended greens and salt. Cook for 10 minutes.
Serve hot with butter and makki di roti.
Heat oil in a pan and sauté chopped onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Stir in chopped tomatoes, turmeric, red chili powder, and salt. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Add fish fillets and coconut milk. Cook until fish is done.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve with rice.
In a pan, heat oil and sauté chopped onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Stir in chopped tomatoes, balchao masala, and salt. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Add cleaned prawns and vinegar. Cook until prawns are done.
Garnish with fresh coriander and serve.
In a pan, heat oil and sauté chopped onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Stir in chopped tomatoes and Chettinad masala. Cook until tomatoes are soft.
Add chicken pieces and salt. Cook until chicken is tender.
Garnish with curry leaves and fresh coriander. Serve hot.
Boil the mixed vegetables until tender.
In a blender, blend grated coconut, yogurt, turmeric powder, and salt into a smooth paste.
Add the boiled vegetables and mix well.
Drizzle with coconut oil and add curry leaves. Mix gently and serve.
Blend soaked rice with coconut milk, yeast, sugar, and salt to make a smooth batter.
Allow the batter to ferment for 6-8 hours.
Heat an appam pan and pour a ladle of batter. Swirl to spread evenly.
Cover and cook until the edges are crispy and the center is soft.
Serve hot with coconut milk or curry.
Heat ghee in a pan and fry onions until golden brown. Set aside.
In the same pan, add garlic and ginger paste, and sauté for a minute.
Add mutton and fry for 5-6 minutes until browned.
Mix in yogurt, turmeric, coriander powder, and red chili powder. Cook until the oil separates.
Add water, cover, and simmer until the mutton is tender.
Top with fried onions and garam masala before serving.
Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for a minute.
Mix in tomato puree, cashew paste, and garam masala. Cook until the oil separates.
Add paneer cubes, cream, and salt. Simmer for 5 minutes.
Serve hot with naan or rice.
Heat ghee in a pot and fry onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a minute.
Add Mutton and fry until browned.
Mix in nihari masala, salt, and enough water to cover the meat. Simmer for 2-3 hours until tender.
Dissolve wheat flour in water and add to the curry. Cook until thickened.
Serve with naan.
In a bowl, mix flour, baking soda, salt, and yogurt. Knead into a soft dough with water. Let it rest for 30 minutes.
Roll out small portions of dough into flat discs.
Cook on a hot tawa or grill until golden spots appear on both sides.
Brush with butter and serve hot.
Fry the bread slices in ghee until golden. Set aside.
Boil milk, sugar, and cardamom powder until it thickens. Add saffron for flavor.
Soak the fried bread in the thickened milk for a few minutes.
Garnish with almonds and pistachios before serving.
Heat ghee in a pressure cooker and add cumin seeds. Sauté until fragrant.
Add sliced onions, green chili, and ginger-garlic paste. Fry until golden.
Mix in rice, lentils, turmeric powder, and salt. Add enough water and pressure cook for 3 whistles.
Serve with a side of pickle and yogurt.
Heat oil in a pan and fry onions, green chilies, and ginger-garlic paste until golden.
Add chicken pieces and fry until browned.
Mix in red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook for 5 minutes.
Add water and simmer until the chicken is cooked through.
Garnish with curry leaves and serve with rice or chapati.
Preheat the oven to 180°C.
In a bowl, mix coconut milk, sugar, and egg yolks until smooth.
Gradually add flour, ensuring no lumps form.
Grease a baking pan with ghee, pour a layer of the mixture, and bake until golden.
Repeat the layering process until the mixture is used up.
Cool, cut into slices, and serve.
Grind garlic, ginger, cumin seeds, and vinegar into a paste.
Marinate the pork with the paste, red chili powder, coriander powder, turmeric, and salt for 2-3 hours.
Heat oil in a pan and fry onions until golden brown.
Add the marinated pork and cook until browned.
Add water and simmer until the pork is tender and the gravy thickens.
Serve with steamed rice or Goan bread.
Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry for a minute.
Mix in chopped tomatoes, coriander powder, red chili powder, and Chettinad masala. Cook until oil separates.
Add boiled eggs and cook in the gravy for a few minutes.
Serve hot with rice or chapati.
Marinate the fish with red chili powder, turmeric powder, ginger-garlic paste, Chettinad masala, lemon juice, and salt. Let it rest for 30 minutes.
Heat oil in a pan and fry the fish fillets until golden and crispy on both sides.
Serve hot with lemon wedges and a side of salad.
Heat oil in a pressure cooker and sauté onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry for a minute.
Mix in chopped tomatoes, coriander powder, red chili powder, and Chettinad masala. Cook until the oil separates.
Add mutton and fry for 5 minutes.
Add water, cover, and cook in the pressure cooker for 20 minutes or until the mutton is tender.
Serve hot with rice or roti.
Soak tamarind in water and extract the juice.
Heat oil in a pan, add mustard seeds and fenugreek seeds. Let them splutter.
Add onions, garlic, and tomatoes. Sauté until soft.
Mix in sambar powder, coriander powder, and salt. Cook until the oil separates.
Add tamarind juice and water. Simmer for 10-15 minutes.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
Heat oil in a pan, add onions, green chilies, and curry leaves. Sauté until onions turn golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry for a minute.
Mix in red chili powder, turmeric, and tamarind extract. Cook for a minute.
Pour in coconut milk and bring to a boil.
Add the fish and simmer until cooked through.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
In a mixing bowl, combine rice flour and salt.
Gradually add water and mix until the flour is moist but not too wet.
Layer a mixture of rice flour and grated coconut alternately in a puttu maker.
Fill the base of the puttu maker with water and steam for about 10-15 minutes.
Once done, remove from the puttu maker and serve hot with banana or coconut milk.
In a pot, add the diced pumpkin, green chilies, turmeric powder, and salt. Add water and cook until the pumpkin is tender.
In a blender, grind grated coconut and cumin seeds into a paste.
Add the cooked red beans and coconut paste to the pumpkin mixture. Mix well and cook for a few more minutes.
In a separate pan, heat oil and add curry leaves. Pour this tempering over the erissery.
Serve hot with rice.
In a large bowl, mix the all-purpose flour, turmeric powder, and salt.
Add oil or ghee and mix well until crumbly.
Gradually add water and knead to form a soft and pliable dough. Cover it with a damp cloth and let it rest for about 30 minutes.
Wash the chana dal and soak it in water for 2-3 hours. Drain the water and cook the dal in a pressure cooker with enough water until soft.
Once cooked, drain any excess water and mash the dal until smooth.

In a pan, add the mashed dal, jaggery, cardamom powder, nutmeg powder (if using), and ghee. Cook over low heat, stirring continuously until the mixture thickens and the jaggery dissolves completely. Let the filling cool.
Divide the dough and filling into equal portions (about 8-10).
Take one portion of dough and flatten it into a small circle. Place a portion of the filling in the center and fold the edges over the filling to seal it. Gently flatten the stuffed dough ball.
Roll it out carefully into a thin circle, dusting with flour to prevent sticking.
Heat a tawa or griddle over medium heat. Once hot, place the rolled-out poli on it.
Cook for about 1-2 minutes until small bubbles appear, then flip it over. Apply ghee on top and cook until both sides are golden brown. Repeat for the remaining dough and filling.
Serve warm with a dollop of ghee or butter. Enjoy!
